subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: In this special episode, Aaron William Perry, founder of the Y on Earth Community and host of the Y on Earth Community Podcast is interviewed by Artem Nikulkov, founder ofEarth Coast Productionsand member of theY on Earth board of Directors.
full_transcript:
[10.2s - 16.8s]: Welcome to the Y Honors Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today,

[17.1s - 22.1s]: we have a very special episode for you as we're visiting here with Artem Nikolkov.

[22.6s - 22.9s]: Hi, Artem.

[23.4s - 23.7s]: Hello, Aaron.

[24.2s - 24.7s]: How are you doing?

[24.7s - 30.8s]: Doing great. And I'm visiting with you here at your location. It's an honor to be here.

[31.4s - 38.6s]: Thank you. Yeah, I'm just thrilled to have you here. And this is the the writers cottage here at Elk Run Farm.

[39.0s - 46.7s]: And also the headquarters for our work at the Y Honors Community. And today in celebration of our

[46.7s - 55.8s]: 100th podcast episode, Artem and I were talking and thought it would be great for him actually to interview me.

[57.1s - 62.3s]: And so without further ado, I'll hand the reins to you, Artem, and take it away.

[62.8s - 69.0s]: Yeah, thank you, Aaron. It's truly an honor being here. And congratulations on the 100th episode.

[69.4s - 75.9s]: That has must have been quite a journey. I know it has been a journey because I've been part of it editing the various episodes

[75.9s - 79.9s]: and the number of interviews that you have held with so many amazing individuals.

[80.7s - 88.2s]: So I'm really curious to hear where you personally feel right now with the Winers Podcast.

[89.1s - 95.4s]: And what your vision is for the future, for the podcast itself, and maybe in the larger sense for our Winers Community.

[96.4s - 110.8s]: Yeah, it's exciting to sort of be at this milestone and both reflecting back on the last 99 episodes and also thinking ahead to what's next.

[111.9s - 121.3s]: And this time of year being kind of the depths of winter is really seasonally speaking a perfect time to be doing that kind of reflection.

[122.3s - 139.6s]: But I got to say one thing which is this that Artem, a huge thank you and sincere gratitude to you and your company Earth Coast Productions and your team, Jordan, Josh, everybody over there.

[139.6s - 152.0s]: And for those who don't know, Artem is on the board of directors of the Y on Earth community and has been tremendously integral to everything we've been doing the last few years.

[152.8s - 166.4s]: And with Earth Coast Productions has been incredibly generous with his time and expertise helping us do all the stuff that we're doing with digital media and web resources and all that kind of stuff.

[166.4s - 177.8s]: So there's a certain, you know, rhyme and reason behind the fact that we chose to do this together. And of course you're also through Earth Coast Productions.

[177.8s - 192.2s]: You're doing video work with all kinds of different great organizations and thought leaders engaged in these questions of stewardship and regeneration and sustainability and health and wellness and community and culture and art.

[192.2s - 205.4s]: And so it's just really fun to be a part of your growing body of citizen journalism, you know, as you're doing your work out in the community. So thank you.

[206.9s - 217.6s]: Yeah, you're welcome. And it has been fun being a part of that journey and supporting Wyn Earth through the website and making the iterative changes there.

[217.6s - 229.6s]: Seeing how you are really developing the vision for Wyn Earth and continuing to build out the community and communicating, connecting with so many diverse individuals.

[230.2s - 242.3s]: It's incredible listening to the number of topics that you bring up from biodynamics to sustainable farming to getting into energy and economics.

[242.3s - 258.6s]: And I mean, it really seems like there is in the topic that you haven't touched or won't touch. And that's incredible because what the world needs right now is for people to understand that this is truly a holistic approach.

[258.6s - 280.6s]: This change that we're all talking about and bringing and stepping into a livelihood that we can all be proud of, of the way that we step on this Earth, it takes that holistic approach where we're looking at every facet of our lives from a new perspective through a new lens, you know, using media terminology.

[283.0s - 299.1s]: And you do that really well. And I'm really excited to see where you go next with it. And as we are coming out of this COVID moment, culturally, you know, the vaccine is out there.

[299.1s - 313.9s]: And I think that we're getting vaccinated and people, however, you know, you may feel about that. I think the world is opening up. And it will still take a few more months. But we will be gathering in person soon enough. It seems.

[313.9s - 330.1s]: And I look forward to seeing why on the road and visiting conferences and engaging with folks in that way, as you've continued to do so digitally through digital means as much as possible.

[330.5s - 336.1s]: So I'm curious what you see what's around the corner there.

[336.7s - 360.6s]: Yeah, it's an interesting question for me to think about. And partly, I think provides the opportunity to talk about how this whole podcast thing got started in the first place. Right, because it's not like we sat down with our other board members. That's Brad Lidge and Katie Garcis and said, oh, we should launch a podcast like that strategically makes a ton of sense.

[360.6s - 382.5s]: That wasn't actually how that happened. Instead, it emerged and evolved very organically. And I know you and I, we were up visiting sustainable settings, one of the sort of mothership biodynamic farms here in Colorado for a workshop and an interviewed brick and interviewed Brooklyn Van and interviewed Stephanie Cison.

[382.5s - 397.0s]: And suddenly we had a couple episodes and then, you know, through zoom, I interviewed Nancy Tuckman from the University of Loyola at Chicago. And she has gone on to found an entire college there now, the sustainability school.

And, and this digital communication allows us in a very succinct format to help share and amplify the voices, the wisdom, the knowledge of so many different educators, thought leaders, scientists, farmers, herbalists, authors.

[437.2s - 457.1s]: And it just kind of kept rolling and it's been so much fun connecting with all of these different folks that we've had on the podcast thus far. And with an eye to how important community is especially in these times, it's actually a very potent way, almost like,

[457.1s - 474.6s]: the Meisilia in a forest, to network with a variety of different thought leaders, organizational leaders, and folks who are also committing substantial parts of themselves and their lives and their professions to this regenerative and stewardship work.

[475.3s - 483.1s]: And so the community building aspect of all of this is really what I think has surprised me most about the podcast series.

[483.1s - 502.2s]: And so now thinking about the next 100 episodes, it's like, boy, this is going to be absolutely tremendous because I think we're going to continue to network and link up with folks not only for the purpose of the episode, but also to figure out how can we best collaborate going forward.

[502.2s - 516.5s]: And those kinds of conversations have been emerging more and more as we've been doing different episodes with folks. I think about John Lou, the founder of ecosystem restoration camps.

[516.5s - 532.4s]: And now we're in conversations about collaborating with that global network to help launch restoration camps right here in Colorado, right here at Elk Run Farm with our friends Nick and Marissa with drylands agro ecology research and others in the region.

[576.6s - 591.0s]: And that's really what I think I'm probably most excited about. And of course, we're cooking up a handful of exciting developments in the Wiener community that we'll be sharing through the course of this year.

[605.5s - 613.8s]: Yeah, definitely exciting times ahead. So you mentioned regenerative camps. What is that all about? What's the concept behind it?

[613.8s - 633.1s]: Yeah, the ecosystem restoration camps movement is now in many countries around the world. The count may be around 30 and they are experiencing explosive growth right now, which is absolutely wonderful and needed and also create some challenges.

[633.1s - 656.0s]: But the basic idea is that communities come together for direct action to restore landscapes, working with permaculture techniques by and large, some are incorporating bio dynamic practices, silver past year, holistic management, creating

[656.7s - 674.1s]: items essentially in different spots around the world, many of which are deserts or have been desertified or severely what's called brittle in an ecological sense, which means are on the front lines of expanding desertification around the world, which is one of the

[674.1s - 704.1s]: severe challenges and risks we face as a global society right now. And so these camps are hundreds and thousands of people mobilizing on the ground with the soil, with plants planting millions of trees and restoring landscapes. And in many cases bringing back greater rainfall and precipitation and helping restore balance to the water systems in places that thousands of years ago or even hundreds of years ago were known to be more loveable.

[705.1s - 724.6s]: And so it's a great honor and I think very important for us to collaborate with ecosystem restoration camps here in our region. And I think part of what we'll be doing through our Ambassador Network is encouraging others in Colorado around the United States and globally to engage and get involved and help create even more of these camps as we go forward.

[725.5s - 740.7s]: Yeah, and what is the Winarth Ambassador'ship program for those that might not be aware of what that's about? Yeah, this has been another one of these really fun sort of organic things that have evolved over the last couple of years.

[740.7s - 770.6s]: We now have something like three to four hundred people engaged as ambassadors of the wider community many are in the United States, but many are all around the globe. And as we've been growing as a small nonprofit organization, we've been developing more tools and framework and infrastructure to help support our ambassadors work in their respective communities to do this community mobilization work for the world.

[770.7s - 788.9s]: We're climate action soil regeneration, culture of kindness, health and wellness, neighborhood resilience. And so we're having a lot of fun now at that point of critical mass where we've got our Ambassador badge system where ambassadors can get you know, acknowledge for different accomplishments.

[788.9s - 805.9s]: If you've taken a permaculture design course, that's a badge, for example, we've got a lot of ambassadors publishing their own videos in some cases, even podcast episodes, even art and papers that are all available for the public on the wider.org website.

[805.9s - 824.1s]: That's the Ambassador publications page. And then we also have Ambassador resources where we're sharing some very special behind the scenes resources with ambassadors that are fully activated to get to those you have to become a fully activated ambassador and there are a few requirements to get to that level.

[824.1s - 840.6s]: But essentially we're now engaged with you know a few hundred folks and not only are we going to deepen what that means for that initial network in our community, but we're also going to be expanding bringing in more and more new ambassadors to our ecosystem.

[840.6s - 853.9s]: And this is where partnerships and collaboration with organizations like the ecosystem restoration camps becomes even more potent essentially amplifying our efficacy as an organization.

[854.3s - 870.3s]: We don't want to reinvent every wheel. We want to collaborate. It's time to mobilize on a planetary scale. And you know, we're living in a moment right now where these next few months and few years literally these next three years are critical in terms of

[876.6s - 896.3s]: Yeah, I know observing the ambassador ship profiles and network grow has been really exciting for me seeing some of the names and cases pop up on the site and knowing that there are people all over the world that are contributing and really getting turned into what you're doing and spreading that message.

We can use it for good and continue to network and really connect with people to with whom otherwise we would just not really be able to connect and so true.

[1637.8s - 1638.9s]: Yeah, absolutely right.
